title: Tell Me How To Get Out Of Bronze
body: Please just tell me how to get out of bronze, I just wanna quit league forever.

replies.body:
Few things:

1. Learn. If you died in certain ways, try to understand why, but just dont repeat the situation you were in.
2. map awareness. Dont see a laner? see bot lane pushed? you are in inner turret and there is no vision? act accordingly.
3. all your team is at base and there is no vision across the map? you think they do baron? dont go! that person will die at 99% of the time, which mean they will get baron and fight in a 4v5 situation.
4. learn all possible positions and play snowbally champs that doesnt depend on your ally to get rolling.
5. watch streams or all informations about all the mechanics of said champs.
6. Value obj and be proactive with pings, dont think how nice your full build would be, think about how you can end the game and do it!
7. develop a good team fight sense. is it better to poke? to go in? who to focus? should you defend your adc? should you team fight at all?
8. Know also when you arent skilled enough to move up. Sometimes to accept it is to grow. Then you will realise how improved you have gotten and you will move up.
9. make suggestions politely, dont ask reasons from ppl about mistakes. just suggest possibilities.
10. CS like a God.
11. play the vision war. encourage your team to understand the value of upgraded trinket
12. know ALL champions, all their abilities, all their dmg (generally speaking) and all the items, when to use them, why and on whom?

>play snowbally champs that doesnt depend on your ally to get rolling.

Care to share what those are?

{{champion:114}} {{champion:120}} {{champion:55}} {{champion:7}} {{champion:76}} {{champion:78}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:62}} {{champion:50}} {{champion:1}} 

the skill caps arent the same for each of those champions. but they are very snowball oriented and can come back from really bad match ups very well. you dont need your ally to get rolling because they all have some sort of initiation or sneaky way to get in and get their kill. even if its ks. once they get money, they get rolling hard.
But... the moment the enemy team groups up... you have to rely on your team. None of those champions can 1v5 :(

....i dont think you understood my post. and im not sure if you are trying to make fun of me or you are being serious. But it sounds you are mocking me. You seriously think im referring 1v5ing? or that im an idiot for suggesting that there is champs that can snowball and carry games?

essentially, i said the word snowball, which is irrelevant of your team.
then i said the word rely to get rolling, which is both on dmg and initiation and powerspike.

{{champion:57}} for instance isnt a snowball champion. you wont carry game or take obj, turrets with him.
there isnt any powerspike point and even if you W in and R into their enemy, you rely on your team dmg and positioning to do the job.

the champs above snowball VERY HARD. wins lane, can zone and take obj (besides the ap midlaners for turrets) they can initiate and delete whoever they want (like the enemy adc or a prime target) they wont need a malphite or a leona to do what they want to do. most of em can splitpush if needed.

But that was my point. There isn't a champion in the game that doesn't have to rely on their teammates. You can have all the gap closers you want, you're not winning 1v5 once the enemy groups up to try to kill you. That means you HAVE to rely on your own team to help and protect you at some point, or you're going to be scared back into your base, unable to defend anything.

In a 5v5 game, there's no champion that can win 1v5 in a regular basis. That would be so broken that the champion would have a 100% banrate. A Master Yi could 1v5 if he's 3 items ahead and the enemy team is mentally disabled or doesn't have any kind of hard CC, but that isn't usually the case.
If you want to win by 1v5ing, you won't learn the game. You have to learn how to play WITH your team, because then the games you can't get rolling, you'll lose as much as you gained the games you did it.

id like to point out that in my posts i mention MANY times the team. the team is important. but i was mentioning a champ that can get rolling with his own high dmg , mobility and set up. for instance. Kog maw isnt a champ that can fill that role because he is highly team dependant. Fiora and wukong much less so and more snowbally.

I absolutely disagree. Yes it is nice to have a champion that can get rolling and snowball like crazy but usually snowbally champions are good duelists. In bronze games rarely end before 35-40 minutes (unless surrendered). What that means is that a champion with a lot of utility is usually going to be more useful because they will have an impact at all points in the game. Hardly any one in bronze knows how to snowball a lead properly and if they do they probably will climb out of bronze very fast. Thus I do not think the idea of playing snowbally champs is very accurate. Instead you should play team fighting champs and be better at them then any one else at your level that way you can snowball and then have a substantial impact when the late game rolls around. Champs like annie are particularly good at this. 

Basically the best advice I can give someone in bronze is pick a champion you like and a champion you like in a different role and only play those 2 champions. Before you know it you won't have to worry about your machanical skills and can instead focus on winning and  objectives and position and all the core elements of the game that are usually not practiced in bronze level play.

i already suggested annie. But you assume many facts about bronze and thats just flat out wrong. 
where did you see that most games never end before 35-40? 100% of games ends up with a nexus being destroyed at the end. Thats all that matters. dont assume they dont know how to snowball or no one knows how to win. now the argument can be made about snowballing  **_properly_**. But you see, that was two or three of my points. People sometimes read what they want to read and dont look at it as a whole. 

6. Value obj and be proactive with pings, dont think how nice your full build would be, think about how you can end the game and do it!
7. develop a good team fight sense. is it better to poke? to go in? who to focus? should you defend your adc? should you team fight at all?

like people think that its a one trick ponie, ohh look play a snowball champ and gg...cmon man...i made 12 points. not one! now you mentioned a champ with utility..

so you would suggest orianna or karma to a bronze 5? you kidding? 
all the advices you said, i already said it

4. **_learn all possible positions_** and **_play snowbally_** champs that doesnt depend on your ally to get rolling.

You said not to play a snowball champ....you serious? you dont want him to play champs that can win lane, win trades,  and teach him out to get ahead and carry? what if his team is super behind...whats the point to team fight with a fatty champ that is behind or at the same level than his lane....what if hes behind since he cant snowball, or cant be ahead?

the bottom line was this: you want to **_TEACH_** him how to get out the best way possible and to **_LEARN_**. hes never going to learn by telling him: oh well man, all games end up late, well cause yall suck, so take a late game champ anyway...thats like the WORST you could tell him. Nothing hes gonna learn from that. Specially telling him about team fights which is usually not the right approach to win in every circumstances. Sometimes split push is in order, sometimes poking. a good part of his games, his team will be behind or one lane will be. Its solo queue: YOU have to carry out of your elo with YOUR skills. Id rather tell him to pick champs that gets ahead and win (and doesnt need mechanics, positining and other fed lanes) cause he will have more options.

I never said people don't know how to snowball in bronze because they do. They do not know how to snowball properly. Basically what it boils down to that the person is in bronze because they are lacking specific important mechanics. SO instead of telling them to play champions they are unfamiliar with/ may not even like. Show them how to be good at their favorite champion in the proper role. If that is Orianna then so be it. If that is Kat that is fine too. Once they get to a point of mastery with the champion they won't have to worry about playing the champion and instead will learn the important stuff like positioning and objectives. SO if your goal is to teach them: having them play snowbally champs really isn't the best way. If you are just trying to help them get out of bronze snowbally champions are probably the best. If you really wanted to teach them how to be a better player you would start with how to play a specific champion. Then move on from their. You don't just start teaching people random things that they can't implement because their skill with a champion is too low to actually complete the task you asked of them.

i think you are either not taking my post as a whole, or you arent trying to understand the heart behind the post. 

look, i understand people wont like necessarily the champs ive mentioned. but there is still a reality check behind it. there is also more than one. but 10. and all different in their role and gameplay. so he can choose.

They flat out are not different in their game style. What the champions kits do yes but not in their gameplay. Riven, wukong, swain, fiora, poppy, and hecarim all want to get into the back line and kill squishies well being tanky (skills or item) enough to survive. Leblanc and kat want to get to the back line and use their high mobility and high damage to kill priority targets and then clean up or get out. Nidalee wants to poke. Annie wants to initiate. 

So if you are advocating a player pick up those champions were only 4 champions have a different role in a team fight you are not covering really any ones play style except for a bruiser player.

What exactly is the reality check. I can't see any.

This is just 100% not true. It is about as hard to carry out as a tank as it is to as a assassin or bruiser. A support usually is significantly harder to carry out of bronze as but still doable.

The game is highly complex yes but people need to start learning somewhere and by learning strategies like split pushing and giving them equal value as team fighting is just absurd. Team fights happen in basically every game in league and are vastly more common then any other strategy. So it makes complete sense to talk about team fights and champions role in team fights.

I also know a tremendous amount of people who can't or couldn't get out of bronze well playing snowbally champs. I also know plenty of people who made it out of bronze playing tanks. Me included. Your stats don't really matter for the topic at hand and using "I know people" is a really bad argument because you can say whatever the hell you want and I have no way to verify it. So the only credentials you have that I can confirm is your gold 5 rank which is lower then mine and your posts which I do not think are very accurate. Which means in my opinion you are not qualified to make the claims you have made.

I have over 6k games played at league. 1 challenger friend (who retired) and 4 diamond 1 friends. thats plenty of data to make a knowledgeable insight.

You say you can't get out of bronze playing tanks, but I know I've done it multiple times.  I don't play much ranked, so back when elo decay would pop you back in bronze before it stopped I'd find myself working my way out of bronze at least once a season.  It's a different mindset.  Instead of setting yourself up to carry, you'd be setting up your teammates to do it.  Like we covered, even in bronze they have some idea how to snowball, so you focus on keeping the enemy contained and your carry safe, and you win.

Now I'm not going to argue about the most effective way to get out of bronze.  The fact is, I never really worried about it too much.  What annoyed me most playing there is that no one seemed to understand how to initiate.  Since that was the thing I found most frustrating, I played champs that could initiate and tower dive.  Then I made sure to lock down anyone trying to escape or kill my carry.  After all, you've usually got a whole team of people convinced it's up to them to solo carry the game.  One person actually setting them up to do so might not always be appreciated, but man, having that person can make a world of difference.

Like I said, I've been in bronze multiple times.  By bringing in what I felt was needed, and not caring about who got what, I've never stayed there long.

you are a reductionist. you are overly simplying things only to something that you value. thats your downfall.

There isnt just team fighting in league. or what to do i nthe team fights. the game is highly complex as a whole and the way you associate the champs are just completely wrong.

I know a tremendous amount of people who plays exactly what you say to play at bronze 5 and they barely can get out of 0 lp. but thats just an exemple. I have over 6k games played at league. 1 challenger friend (who retired) and 4 diamond 1 friends. thats plenty of data to make a knowledgeable insight.

I know that. I was trying to make it clear so noone can think that just by picking those champions you are going to automatically be able to win every game regardless of your teammates. Trusting 4 random people every game is hard if you're not used to it, but being able to understand who of them are going to impact the game the most and "using" their impact to win is more effective than tryin to snowball alone desperately.

Note: I'm a support main so my experience influences my point of view a lot. It's not the only way, but it's my way.

it wasnt to you. however

''doesnt rely on your allies to**_ get rolling_**'' says what it says pretty clearly

Not like a nasus or ryze who needs their team including jungle intervention to get rolling and survive in team fights environment 
it would go against all my points for one, and for two, since when did anyone 1v5d their way to challenger? that in itself doesnt require clarification. i think everyone know what i was saying. snowballing champ is what it is. carrying is what it is. i dont see streamers being corrected everytime they are being asked advices. (but wait, you cant 1v5.) no one ever said that either. tho many streamers do say to carry on your own and screw ur teamates mistakes and open the gates: aka trick2g, but he isnt the only one.

I don't know why people are arguing against these points: The question was how to get out of Bronze, not how to become Challenger or even Gold. The advice offered works for that level, and is applicable to higher levels. Teamfight orientated champs help a lot in higher games, but in Bronze (which from my experience a long time ago) matches end quickly, they don't drag, because mistakes are made far more often. Champs that are great in team fights struggle because your team is so disorganised that if they are not at your level, you won't go up to silver.
But champs that can shine on their own, CAN carry a team, not because they can 1v5, but because the enemy team is equally disorganised and struggle to stop that 11 kill Yi no matter how many times they try. Being good at these champs gets you going, it doesn't mean you're great, and saying that "people don't know how to snowball and if they do they rise out of Bronze quickly" was the point Beoridas was making, if you are STUCK in bronze but can play at higher level, use these champs to reach the higher level, then you can work on the areas your are not good at to push even higher.

An Annie who 5-man stuns can :P
Done it twice already, granted I was waaaaaay ahead

-.- Fine. Most champions, if they have 6 items versus a 2-3 item enemy team could potentially 1v5 the enemy team, given the enemy team is retarded enough.

Lets be realistic though.

I was lvl 11 stunning 7s-10s. I had ludens and deathcap for ap and no one bought mr. I'd made sure not to let them see my damage. I grinned at the 5-man stun ending with "PENTAKILL!!!" So funny. Yet, stuck in bronze 4 D= 
SAVE ME SENPAI!!!!

you need to remove the ''stuck'' from you vocabulary :p. play the champs ive mentioned. main them even. watch someone play them at the high elo. get a feel. 

then read my points, learn them. A lot of the game is decision making and when to make them. the rest are branches, important branches but the core still remain the same.

Your advice is well intention but is pretty flawed. Any champion in the game, including Nasus, can hard carry a game. they don't "need" a team to get going they just need a player that can consistently win with them. Jumping from champion to champion is the plague of bronze q. People would be much better served picking 1-2 champions and only playing those. Also those champions you listed may or may not have anything to do with the person's play style or they might not even actually like them. 

You are correct a lot of the game is decision making. However proper decision making is very very difficult when you are constantly trying to learn champions. So settle down to a few make playing them muscle memory so you can instead focus on the more important parts of the game.

i never said that they should jump champions. I never said you cant hard carry with other champions.

What i did say however, in the context anyway is this: Play a champion that win trades, that can get ahead and push its advantage very well.

Nasus you see is the worst example you can give. Specially at lower elo. He loses most match up, requires actually skills early game, will need jungle intervention more often than not, and is VERY SELFISH in his gameplay. He needs the stacks or he will NEVER be relevant (or way too late)

Also, the champs ive mentions are not just one role. there is 10 roles in 10 champs ive mentioned.  what do you mean they may not like the gameplay? 10 roles!!!!! the point is winning. if they like janna and thats all they want to play, no problemo, but they cant complain about bronze 5 and not climbing in the best way possible.

you cant snowball and hard carry with tanks but with one exception: {{champion:106}} 

{{champion:114}} is a melee adc. a bruiser? really? (top lane, mid lane)
{{champion:120}} Is a bruiser, but hes a highly mobile, hybrid dmg aoe bruiser. (top lane, mid lane, jungle)
{{champion:50}} is a DoT sustain Mage ....a bruiser..lol (mid lane, sometimes top)
{{champion:62}} CAN be a bruiser, but hes rather an assassin due to his ratios. (top lane and mid lane)
{{champion:92}} is a full high dmg mobile bruiser, but her gameplay is more like assassin/melee adc type (top lane, sometimes mid lane)
{{champion:78}} Anti-carry assassin (top lane, jungle)
{{champion:76}} Mobile Mage Poke assassin (Top lane, mid lane, jungle)
{{champion:7}} Single targeted ranged Assassin (mid lane)
{{champion:55}} Aoe targeted melee assassin (mid lane)
{{champion:1}} Burst utility Mage (mid lane, rarely top lane, support)

your classification was mostly wrong. so you tell me these guys are all the same and cant be played differently at different positions.

you are just super biased. You can absolutely hard carry and snowball super hard as tanks. If the recent perma ban on sej didn't show you that I don't know what will.

Poppy, fiora, hecerim, swain, wukong, riven, and poppy all play very similarly in the sense that they all have similar roles in a team fight. They all want to get into the enemies ranks and deal a lot of damage well being tanky enough to survive or have skills that make them slippery. Assassins are usually the clean up crew or they kill high priority targets and get out.  Fiora like swain will try to go into the team and do a lot of damage well not dieing but has no reliable way of getting out, which is like hecerim, wukong, riven, and poppy.

The vast majority of games are won by team fights. it is very very rare for any other strategy to produce a win. Especially at Bronze. So it isn't really very relevant to talk about escaping bronze and then talking about split pushing or siege comps.

the options are large. not just the team fighting aspect which you prone. and its learning all the stuff you can do to win other than team fighting that will get you far at the game. if that means killing the carries (and its the point of this game to win) then let it be. supports and tanks wont do that as i mentioned below.

Also: there is thousands over thousands of interactions in the game and strenght and weaknesses. thats part of play style and gameplay. not just team fighting and who to kill to win. duh. obv you have to kill the carries to win. hence the point.

It isn't even about the champions being different they are. It comes down to playstyle. they all have a very specific similar playstyle. One that you just would not have any a different role. For example: compare Annie to swain, fiora, or hec. They are light years different and require a completely different playstyle. All those champions you mentioned, well different, don't really require a different playstyle.

i can understand where you come from. but the game doesnt revovle around team fights alone and what you do with it. so you are classifying every genre just by what they do in the fight and how they do it. thats an abolutely wrong way to look it at and shortsighted. their build, their kit, their obj control, their split push capability, their laning, sieging, all change who they are.

fiora and swain do want to get in the backline yes. but they are very different champions. and its not simply walking to the back. their laning is also VERY different and their match up is different.  their roles also states their niche. The reason they are picked i nthe first place. i wouldnt pick poppy in a tank warfare. even if she needs to get in the back line.  the game is highly more complex than you make it out to be

sej perma ban is just bandwagon.  she isnt as strong as she used to be. and people ban her mostly at low elo not because she hard carry. but because the meta favors her a lot more than other junglers. hence giving an adv to the team that has her. 
Also, low elos tend to perma ban assassins and aoe tanks.

so all in all. the excuse that they may not want to play none of these due to their limited role is very limited in foresight. they are all super different from one another. wukong and riven being the most similar, tho wukong excels in team fights, deception and tank fighting, while riven at assassination and mobility

While this is true some can do it much easier than others. You're going to need more than luck to 1v5 with someone like malzahar or urgot. I could be wrong here but if I'm not mistaken your reply is to a reply I made regarding fiora, riven, poppy, and annie. If I'm mistaken then feel free to disregard this post.

Those four champions can hard carry a game and it's possible for them to win fights that they have no business getting close to where others would simply die a quick painful death. Aatrox and darius could also be on that list. Going through the list these champions excel at either 
1) nuking people(fiora, riven, darius) to the point where it doesn't matter how many people you bring, it only matters if they walked into a death bush or not. Those three can 100-0 nearly any non-tank in about a second. both fiora and riven have really low cooldowns also so they can repeat as needed until they ace or finally die. darius just dunks.

2) How the hell am I alive champions. poppy is a prime example of this one and to some degree annie. Poppy(I really love poppy) can live through fights no other champion can with her broken as hell passive and ult you can run into a 1v5 and if you can find a good ult target dismember any damage dealers on their team then clean up the tanks or force them to flee. Annie can do this also to some degree but you gotta get a surprise tibbers on it. baron and dragon pit are two places she can easily erase the back line then walk away from anyone left alive stunning as needed. This is what I meant by luck. positioning and choke points.

Now to avoid any confusion if any of these champs get caught out or death bushed they are likely to fall over dead(except poppy). But they can cause enough damage and disruption to pull off fights that are heavily stacked against them. These are simply champions that can carry hard and don't require the rest of your team to make something happen.

Also I make no claim that this list is complete but in my own experience these are champions to learn if you want to carry a game. They all scale into late game  and have the potential to win games single handedly. I'm down in the muck of bronze and teamwork is not something we excel at. If you want out you must carry unless you get insanely lucky and have a team that works together. If they do that then by all means stay and fight by their side. I personally can't carry my way out yet but I'm working on it.

Sorry for rambling. Sleep deprivation is a bitch.

This guy made a really good post. I would say that number 4 is a bit off, as long as you play support you could probably get away with two others, but I would say learn 3 others to be safe. I don't play Adc and it isn't really an issue for me at all. I used to have a tune page for it but deleted it bc I never really played it and don't like it.

Also I would say learn stuff you are good at making the best of. I play heimer almost 70% of games and he isn't a snowball champ and my win % with him is really good. I know how to use him to control objectives and push towers so I can win with him and it a style I like better than snowball champs. Find what you like and practice. Assume it is always your fault when you lose no matter how bad your team and look for what you could have done better. The game may have been a loss no matter how you played but doing this forces you to look at every death, every time you didn't get a kill, every trade you ended with less hp, and try to learn from it.

he isnt snowbally, but he pushes and protect objective amazingly. Also hes on the strong side. The only reason why i recommended the others compared to him is that he isnt mobile or pick a target and destroy it type

Also he excels at being engaged on, rather than engage and isnt a split pusher per se. So he depends on the enemy's mistakes or engages, then the rest is conditional. thats too risky imo. Snowballing is very important at lower elo since they usually dont know how to deal with it. id take a fed riven, fiora to a fed heim any day.

The only pro i know who climbed up to challenger maining support is Lemon Nation. Other than that its Adcs, jungle, mid lane. in order. at lower elos its getting ahead and how to manage that advantage. which a support cannot do in anyway shape of form.  a support is better at limiting your team's mistakes or protecting the advantage your team has. So yes, its an important role. but **_not the role to carry your way out of bronze in the best way possible_**

Oh yeah, I definitely agree support is not the role to carry your self if you want to do it the fastest. I was just saying that you NEED to know how to play it decently. There are people who will say they don't know how to support or aren't good at it when they are last pick, and you know what, they are often getting it anyway. If you cannot play support well enough that you aren't holding your team back that's an issue because it is something you WILL have to play at some point. All though I would argue that support type champs can be really good to carry with. S3 Nunu was really strong in the jungle and he is definitely a support style jungle but he carried my bad self to gold (which is the only time I made gold, and him and Janna were probably the only champs I could play to the level that I would do well or decent in a gold mmr game). 

It is as much about what you play well as it is about what is strong is the perspective I was trying to bring.
